Determine what the polynomial f(x) looks like when f(x) = 5 at four distinct integers x = a, b, c, d.
Construct a polynomial g(x) from f(x) such that g(x) = f(x) - 5, and identify the roots and degree of g(x).
Analyze g(x) to understand its properties and the conditions under which f(x) can also take the value 8.
Set up the equation for h(x) = f(x) - 8 and identify the difference between the polynomials g(x) and h(x).
Determine the number of roots the equation h(x) = 0 can have based on the degree of the polynomial and the given information about g(x).
Consider the possible degrees of f(x) and how this affects the degree of h(x).
Discuss any theorems or principles that restrict the number of integer solutions h(x) = 0 can have, such as the Integer Root theorem.
Summarize the findings and establish an upper bound for the number of integer values k for which f(k) = 8 based on the preceding analysis.

Write a new polynomial g(x) such that g(x) = f(x) - 5, and identify its roots.
Determine the degree of polynomial g(x).
Explore the constraints on the values of g(x) at integers other than a, b, c, d such that f(x)=8. Define a new relationship for these constraints.

Analyze how the degree of the polynomial g(x) limits the number of roots for polynomial h(x).
Calculate the potential maximum number of integer roots of h(x) using its degree.

Understand the given conditions: f(x) is a polynomial with integer coefficients and f(x)=5 at x=a, b, c, d.
Recognize what it means for a polynomial to have a value of 5 at four distinct integer points — a, b, c, d.
Determine the minimum degree of the polynomial given that it has at least four roots.
Formulate a new polynomial g(x) = f(x) - 5, and determine its roots and factors.
Consider the effect of the polynomial g(x) having specific roots a, b, c, and d.
Consider any additional factors g(x) might have beyond (x-a)(x-b)(x-c)(x-d).

Analyze the roots and possible values of h(x).
Calculate how many integer roots h(x) could potentially have based on its degree and known roots.
Summarise the possibility and constraints on k, for which f(k)=8, based on the behavior of h(x).

Express the difference between f(x) and 5, say g(x), which should have roots at x = a, b, c, d.
Determine the general form and degree of g(x) given it has roots at x = a, b, c, d.
Study the possibility of f(x) = 8, in other words, set g(x) = 3 (since f(x) = 5 + g(x) and solve for g(x) = 8 - 5).
Analyze how the degree of g(x) impacts the number of roots/values k where g(k) = 3.
Evaluate at most how many distinct integer values of k can satisfy the equation g(k) = 3, assuming the degree and leading coefficient of the polynomial g(x).
Summarize the findings to state the maximum number of integer roots possible for g(k) = 3 based on polynomial degree n.
Discuss the relevance of continuity and the integer coefficients constraint in concluding the maximum possible number of solutions k.
